frege.rt

Class Boxed<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • frege.rt.Boxed<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Lazy<Boxed<T>>, Value

    public final class Boxed<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Value, Lazy<Boxed<T>>

    Container for arbitrary java reference values.

    Used by the compiler to encode native reference types.

    A declaration 

     data X = native "some.reference.type" where
      // member function declarations ...

    creates a noninstantiable class TX that serves as namepsace for the member functions. Yet, the java type for frege type X is always Boxed<some.reference.type>

    In addition, for each primitive type supported by frege, there is a nested class Boxed.type where type is the name given that type in frege. Hence, Boxed.Int is a boxed primitive int.

    • Field Detail

      • j

        public final T j

        Reference to the java object.

        This is used in calls to native methods, which could be member functions of the type T.

        Frege assumes that this field is never null. Null values could be introduced by native functions whose return type is incorrectly specified or by array accesses.

      • unboxObject

        public static final java.lang.invoke.MethodHandle unboxObject

        public static final java.lang.invoke.MethodHandle unboxInt

      • coerce

        public <N> Boxed<N> coerce()
        This is needed in cases where the type argument has itself type arguments that must be corrected because java does not understand higher kinded type variables.

      • arrayNew

        public static final <T extends Lazy<T>> T[] arrayNew(int size)

        Create an array with T elements.

        This works so long as we never try to cast the array implicitely or explicitely to its supposed type. Therefore, native arry types like StringArray need their own special array creation routines.

        Parameters:
        size - the size of the array

      • arrayUpd

        public static final <T> T[] arrayUpd(T[] arr,
               int i,
               T v)

        Update array nondestructively.

        Parameters:
        arr - the array
        i - index into arr
        v - new value to set at index i
        Returns:
        a new array that looks like the old one except that there is value v at index i

      • arraySet

        public static final <T> void arraySet(T[] arr,
                int i,
                T v)

        Update array destructively. This method is not pure!

        Parameters:
        arr - the array
        i - index into arr
        v - new value to set at index i

        Changes the passed array, therefore it is not pure. Because the return type is void there is no way to make the frege compiler believe it is pure.

      • arrayGet

        public static final <T> T arrayGet(T[] arr,
             int i)

        Get array element.

        Parameters:
        arr - the array
        i - index into arr
        Returns:
        the value at index i, which may be null
